title: How to Sew a Sequin on Fabric

steps.headline: Begin with fine, long needle and suitable thread.
steps.description: The thread should be fine and strong; silk or cotton are good natural choices while polyester thread is long-lasting. Place the needle and thread on the underside of the fabric where you intend sewing the sequin into place. Match the thread to the color of the sequin rather than to the fabric.

steps.headline: Place the sequin with care on the top side of the fabric, sitting in the position that you want it to be.
Bring the needle up through the fabric.
steps.description: Draw it through the center of the sequin. Leave a long tail of thread on the underside.

steps.headline: Return to the backside of the fabric.
steps.description: Cross the thread over the top of the sequin.

steps.headline: Tie the ends of the thread together on the back side to create secure knot.
Move on to the next sequin.
steps.description: The more that you sew, the faster this will become as you get used to the rhythm of going through the motions. When sewing sequins in a row, be sure that they're not overlapping unless this is the final look you wish to achieve.

text: Begin with fine, long needle and suitable thread. The thread should be fine and strong; silk or cotton are good natural choices while polyester thread is long-lasting. Place the needle and thread on the underside of the fabric where you intend sewing the sequin into place. Match the thread to the color of the sequin rather than to the fabric. Place the sequin with care on the top side of the fabric, sitting in the position that you want it to be.  Bring the needle up through the fabric. Draw it through the center of the sequin. Leave a long tail of thread on the underside. Return to the backside of the fabric. Cross the thread over the top of the sequin. Tie the ends of the thread together on the back side to create secure knot.  Move on to the next sequin. The more that you sew, the faster this will become as you get used to the rhythm of going through the motions. When sewing sequins in a row, be sure that they're not overlapping unless this is the final look you wish to achieve.
